captions.text:
It can be tough to remember all the elemental 
matchups in Pokémon, can&#39;t it? It&#39;s like learning

your times tables except with mutant electric 
camels instead of numbers and without your mum

locking you in the downstairs toilet until you 
prove you can recite it from memory. I find it

helpful to come up with mental associations. 
Water type is strong against Fire type because

water puts out fire. See how easy this is? Fairy 
type is strong against Fighting type because Mike

Tyson would find it very humiliating to wear a 
tutu. Ghost type is strong against Psychic type

because James Randi is dead, and now his ghost 
haunts the estate of Uri Geller. But remember

Ghost type doesn&#39;t take reduced damage from 
Psychic type because the mainstream media remains

complicit in the circulation of pseudoscience 
and anti-intellectualism. Or was it the other

way around? Well, anyway, you see how tricky this 
can be. Perhaps that&#39;s why the new Pokémon game,

Pokémon Legends ZA, has provided us the 
opportunity to learn all the nuances of Pokémon

battling by giving us an environment in which we 
can do it without being distracted by silly things

like aesthetics, engaging characters, meaningful 
exploration, or an even half-decent plot.

The Pokémon franchise has, in recent years, 
taken a rather obnoxious &quot;We&#39;re the only one,

so why try harder?&quot; attitude. I mean, where 
else are you going to go for your cutesy,

animal-collecting, elemental matchup cockfighting 
simulator? Fucking Palworld? Not after our lawyers

are done with it, motherfucker. Nintendo and 
Game Freak know damn well they have us all

by the undercarriage here. Literally, in the case 
of when my kids fight over who gets to wear their

special Eevee-patterned underpants. As such, all 
the recent Pokémon games have been set in bland,

pastelly environments where stiffly animating, 
blank-eyed characters stand around modelling hot

pants, their heads snap-rotating to look at the 
current speaker with each line of dialogue like

a set of model railroad switches watching 
a tennis match. I think the moment I knew

Pokémon Legends ZA wasn&#39;t planning to buck 
that trend was in the first 10 minutes when

I saw a generic man next to one of those green 
praying mantis lads with the scythes for arms,

both standing perfectly still and staring 
at a random bush. And when I spoke to them,

the dude announced, &quot;We&#39;re trimming the 
hedges!&quot; I mean, they could&#39;ve at least

turned on an attack animation. I thought they 
were engaged in competitive no-hands urinating.

Anyway, the setup is we are another in a long 
line of generic, blank-eyed, teenage Pokémon

protagonists and we have come to a city that is 
allegedly the Pokémon world&#39;s equivalent of Paris

but doesn&#39;t seem like it smells nearly enough 
of human excrement. The reason why you came

to Not Paris is left unestablished and becomes 
moot when you get flagged down by a random girl

seconds after arriving who invites you to live 
in her hotel for free. She then enlists you in

the local Pokémon battling league because she 
can just tell that you&#39;re one of those rare 1%

of Pokémon trainers with the preternatural 
ability to know that you&#39;re allowed to have

more than four of the fuckers. And that you 
don&#39;t have to stick to only one Pokémon type

just because it coordinates with your outfit. Oh, 
and would you also like to join our unsanctioned

vigilante group dedicated to calming down 
rogue superpowered wild Pokémon by smacking

the absolute primary-colored tits off of them? 
That would usually be the point that a realistic

person would start thinking there&#39;s maybe a few 
too many strings attached to getting to stay in

this psycho girl&#39;s spare bedroom, but what can 
we do? There&#39;s only ever two dialogue options,

and they&#39;re usually &quot;yes&quot; or &quot;yes and 
also here&#39;s my social security number.&quot;

I keep calling it Pokémon Legends ZA because I&#39;m 
very fond of the fact that ZA is an acceptable

word in Scrabble, but it&#39;s more accurately Pokémon 
Legends Z-A, as at the core of things is a No

More Heroes-style ladder tournament in which we 
climb from Z rank to A rank by grinding up random

battles and then doing promotion matches against 
specific characters of equal rank. Don&#39;t fret,

though; there&#39;s a story beat at one point where 
the game bumps you up about 15 ranks in one go

when it realizes it doesn&#39;t have nearly enough 
going on to sustain our interest that long like

a harassed DM with visibly bored players suddenly 
announcing that the ceiling&#39;s looking conveniently

unstable. I mean, the entire game takes place 
within the confines of Less Filthy Paris, and

most of the buildings look the same, so there&#39;s no 
sense of being on a grand adventure of discovery

that previous Pokémon publications purport to 
present. There&#39;s a day/night cycle wherein you

battle trainers during the night and during 
the day hunt wild Pokémon in designated &quot;wild

zones&quot; of the city that increase in number as time 
passes. With no mention of how the people living

in those zones feel about that or why no one seems 
particularly bothered about living in what amounts

to a Last of Us-style apocalypse with big-eyed, 
hyper-colored angry chipmunks instead of zombies.

Actually, I didn&#39;t see much point in hunting 
Pokémon in wild zones from about the halfway

point when I had assembled six dudes who covered 
basically all the elements and could just focus on

levelling them. And then the game introduced 
&quot;mega evolution,&quot; wherein a fully evolved

character temporarily gains one more, somehow even 
more stupidly designed form with superpowers. And

if this were a Saturday morning cartoon, I&#39;d 
assume this was a measure intended to sell a

new round of action figures &#39;cause I wouldn&#39;t 
say it enhances the classic Pokémon formula,

it just disincentivizes anything but focusing on 
a core group of lads even further &#39;cause it&#39;s only

a select number of specific Pokémon that even can 
mega evolve, and from a certain point, every boss

fight and promotion match is against mega-evolved 
dudes, and showing up without one is like showing

up to a party on Epstein Island without bringing 
your own heavily soundproofed fursuit. Yeah,

I&#39;ll let you think about that one for a bit. 
The big change in the combat is that it&#39;s now

real time with attack cooldowns, which I don&#39;t 
hate. It bridges the gap between turn based and

real time a hell of a lot better than Legends: 
Arceus&#39; method, which was to awkwardly call a

timeout mid-battle and do some turn-based 
rounds like it was fuckin&#39; chess boxing.

In the real-time cooldown system, we can negate 
damage by—shocking as this sounds—getting out

of the way of things. Man, why has no one ever 
thought to try that during a penalty shootout?

And for the first time in Pokémon, I&#39;m using buff 
and debuff moves &#39;cause all my damagers are still

warming up. It&#39;s the invisible cooldowns that 
get annoying. You can pause the game to use a

recovery item, but then you can&#39;t use any more 
for a time. How much time? Who the fuck knows?

I didn&#39;t see any indicator to that effect; I&#39;d 
just have to hang out in the corner of the arena,

dodge-rolling under water beams and mashing menu 
buttons like a panicky motorist who mistook a

carwash for a McDonald&#39;s drive-thru. Also, after 
you call a Pokémon in, you can&#39;t actually command

it until it&#39;s had a chance to pose for a few 
seconds, but I think this might be an attempt to

recreate the classic turn-based Pokémon scenario 
where you miss a turn to switch Pokémon and the

enemy promptly piledrives your reinforcement into 
a wastepaper basket because they get a turn first.

So, this all seems to be spiraling into the 
hair-clogged shower drain of ending summary,

which is thus: it&#39;s still reflecting Pokémon&#39;s 
general lack of interest in putting any effort

into story and aesthetics whatsoever, 
but it is better than Pokémon Legends:

Arceus. For whatever that&#39;s worth. I mean, 
so is being licked by an estranged relative.
